title: Friday, 8th February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

It's one of those days when there's absolutely loads happening and I can't mention any of it.

BE11:03am

Also: good morning. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily etc.

VV75 morning
DRichi Good morning
AmInvest Morning

When was the last time we started with a picture?

It's been a week at least. So, here, have a picture.

(Usually referred to as the first Pat Val, though it wasn't. The original was round the corner in Frith Street until the Germans bombed it.)

Phil Looking forward to finding out how Ocado managed to burn their Warehouse to a crisp.
Lemmy £2.70 for a croissant, finally the Met acts

Phil Lemmy: London for you.

We will use all available legal means to protect the company and in particular our employees and their personal rights. Wirecard is taking legal actions against FT and its unethical reporting.

rw42 To continue yesterday's moan - yes i know i can switch twitter back to timeline view. I just really resent having to do it every other time i open the app! There seems to have been a tipping point recently from designing UIs to do what you want, and remember how you like things, to nagging you into getting used to what's most profitable for the advert slingers!

Uh huh.

nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:14am

While it is always difficult to make up one’s mind with such a complex case, we believe management has been rather convincing last Monday. We keep our Buy rating and EUR225 TP.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Uh huh.

BE11:15am

While the article looks very well documented and precise, Wirecard fully
denied again all allegations and confirmed the statements made last Monday. According to the IR, the FT article just details the allegations from the whistleblower, in the hands of the independent lawyers in Singapore (Rajah & Tann) for some time, which are totally wrong. While Rajah & Tann just mentioned
last Monday that they have made no conclusive findings of criminal
misconduct from any employee of Wirecard so far, the results of the
investigations could be published in the coming weeks. In the meantime, the auditors (EY) should fully validate the 2018 accounts, which will be published on 4 April, potentially bringing some relief.

BE11:15am

Hm.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

While Wirecard management looks fairly convinced that there is nothing
behind the allegations, it is always difficult to make up its mind with such a complex case. That said, the suspicious transactions mentioned in the article look fairly limited (only EUR8m) as compared to Wirecard’s size (EUR2.1bn sales in 2018), including suspicious EUR3m revenue in Hong Kong from Right Momentum Consulting, EUR3m from Aprisma in Indonesia (Wirecard’s acquisition in on-line and mobile banking in Indonesia in 2014) and a EUR2m flows transfer from Hong Kong to India.

red tcg shareholders...brave souls
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Overall, the group's FY19 expectations are unchanged (no quantitative
guidance). The market data for online traffic suggests that demand is down c.10-15% in January, and TUI's profit warning implies ASPs have deteriorated by c.2 ppts in the period, we estimate. Whilst TCG's proactive capacity cuts have supported early pricing (c.30% sold), we are cognisant that the strong growth by peers will likely put further downward pressure on market pricing as the season progresses. We believe that this, coupled with inflation still in positive territory, risks further margin deterioration in the TO in FY19. Its trading data and taking a conservative stance on summer TO ASPs (NSe +3.2%), our FY19 EBIT estimate falls c.5% from £276m to £263m and EPS falls from 7.0p to 6.4p. We now forecast Net Debt as of Sep19 of £383m from £371m.

Imperialist @red - awaiting consolidation
Flaneur @red - Auditors being useless highlighting issues in a business - thats prob why they were hired
BE11:24am

And Bernstein on the airline sale .....

BE11:24am

While a deal could alleviate some of TCG's balance sheet problems (last year its net debt position increased from EUR 40mn to EUR 389m, TCG posted a negative FCF and needed to renegotiate its bank covenants), we wonder which trade buyer could be interested in a current structurally challenged market environment. We point out that while TCG's airline offers some attractive cost and yield economics (which are in part due to its in-house booking channel), it is operating an old and unappealing fleet to any potential buyer and operates on a high degree of crowded routes. Management has confirmed that it is considering all options, as well as a partial airlines split.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

While we rate TCG Market-Perform we update our TP to 45p, as our 2019 EPS come down 22.1%, given the current unquantifiable risks (Brexit, competitive pressures, airline yield drops, airline split), we would not be an advocate of buying the stock.

BE11:25am

And MOST.

red @Flaneurgotcha. just another tax essentially
BE11:25am

Cutting EPS forecasts ~20%, price target reduced to 50p

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Which is still 100% upside, but they're still neutral.

Tom Dalgleish Are those "uh huh's" of the cognoscenti re the unprintable about Wirecard
BE11:26am

Because the debt is always going to get in the way of any case for buying the equity.

BE11:26am

The company navigated its way through the December cash low point, and confirmed it had headroom of £150-200m, which it described as its minimum buffer, though this is well below the £400m buffer last year. It also met its December covenant test, having extended covenants with its banks in advance. The company expects free cash flow to be positive this year, but we forecast an £80m outflow due to a working capital outflow and exceptionals. The increase in the company's trade payables and receivables has contributed to a ~£460m working capital inflow since FY12, and any move back in payable days could reverse some of this, particularly if
revenues drop this year as we forecast or suppliers demand earlier payment (e.g. here). This suggests its cash buffer could fall below its minimum level later this year, implying it would need to raise funds. On a gross adjusted leverage basis we estimate debt was 4.1x EBITDA at Dec-18, and 3.5x on a basic net leverage basis, which compares to TUI on 2.8x and 0.9x respectively. Given the leverage, and the capital constraints to expansion, the decision to undertake a strategic review of the airline looks sensible to us.

red wouldnt dream of suggesting anyone buys tcg but what is the idea behind a 50p tgt yet being neutral? hold if u have it, however do not buy?

11:36 am
BE11:37am

As per Barclays .....

BE11:37am

[T]he activities that relate to the charges admitted by a former employee, carry a monetary value amounting to over US$4.5bn. They also fall within the scope of the Bribery Act of 2010, having occurred since 2012. UK law is very clear in the penalty for corporate bribery, it being set at 20-400% of the gross profit obtained in the contracts, depending on culpability, which ca10% gross margin for the E&C division would imply a $90-1,800mn potential liability (GBp20-408/share). Thursday’s fall in market capitalisation was around 40% of the high value. At this juncture nothing has been forthcoming from the company and indeed part of it appears, to us, to refer to invoices that were disputed in court in 2017 by an agency/consultancy hired by Petrofac. We would expect to hear something soon from the company, but in the mean time investors need to evaluate the stock. Our analysis based on the trading of other Engineering & Construction peers (E&C) is that the stock carries an extra discount of US$1.6bn (355p/share), significant and offering upside should clarity and mitigation become available.

FJ TATA makes history

11:39 am

red @Tom Dalgleishwhat are u supposed to do, just look at it ;)
BE11:39am

Barclays again:

BE11:40am

[O]ur price target includes a discount of US$800mn for a potential liability based on the maximum 4x multiplier on the assumption that the issues that were being investigated related to US$2bn of workload in Kazakhstan. The current escalation triples this potential.

red i dont think may and tusk will ever share cake
Tom Dalgleish Never eat cake
11:40 am
BE11:41am

We stress that is only an estimation of the worse case as it stands with current information. We also note that the range of possibilities, is wide. US$800mn would still be more than the gross margin we would expect on the total workload, ie a greater than 1x multiplier. It would also be almost double what we expect the company would have made on the newly highlighted projects alone. In effect the US$800mn discount that we apply to our price target, moves from realm of a maximum potential liability to a possible outcome, if indeed any inappropriate conduct is proven. It would also be a record penalty for the SFO, surpassing the US$612mn penalty that Rolls Royce faced and be in the order of magnitude of the cumulative penalties that SBM Offshore faced via settlements in Brazil, the US and Holland, albeit all differing sentencing jurisdictions to the SFO. Applying the top end of the penalty range to the new contracts, adds a potential new liability of US$1.8bn and makes the potential liability US$2.6bn in total. Clearly there are a lot of moving parts that would have to make this an actuality.

FATDAZ @nately my take is that those that bought the business down likely did so without any concern for the ordinary employees though too my knowledge their motives are not yet clear - I think its shame that company that was trading well shopuld have been derailed in that way - but do take your point about entrepreneurs VCs etc setting up biz in first place

red thing about sse and others that run wind farms for me it is that they obviously dont work when there is no wind, but when its quite windy they often dont work either. misses the point of the whole thing for me.

St Andrean @red. Windfarms purpose in life is to massage Green Egos. No commercial rationale once you strip the support payments away
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Have Goldman to summarise.

BE11:52am

We see this statement overall as a negative for sentiment as SSE capacity market revenues are removed from EPS guidance until more clarity is given on the status of the UK capacity market by the EC. We continue to be Buy rated as the company’s fundamentals remain strong. At the current share price, SSE offers an attractive combination of an inexpensive valuation with scope for sizeable value creation via the upcoming UK renewable auctions (May 2019). SSE has 5.1GW of projects (either owned or via partnerships), or 63% of the total projects bidding, in the UK Contract for Difference Auctions this year. We see the auctions as a key opportunity for SSE to secure the next leg of growth and value; in our SoTP we assume it wins 2GW of capacity, adding 115p/share of value (11% of the current share price).

BE11:53am

And Caz, with more of a summary type summary.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

SSE this morning released a Q3 trading statement which included the following key points: 1) EPS guidance range for the current FY19 period reduced by 6p to 64p to 69p on account of the capacity market suspension, 2) SSE Energy Services lost another c.160k customers in the quarter, which equates to 10% annualised rate of churn, 3) A number of elements of guidance have been reaffirmed including 5yr dividend expectations, capital expenditure, capital management of £200m, low effective tax rate in FY19 and intentions to dispose of SSE Energy Services, and lastly 4) While renewables output was solid in Q4, January production was c.25% below plan. In addition to the customer losses reported in SSE Energy Services management has indicated that working capital movements might drive cash flow into negative territory in FY19 or FY20, likely due to the impact of the sharp rise in wholesale prices and the price cap. The reduction in guidance due to the capacity market was broadly expected, as was a degree of customer losses in Energy Services, so overall we would expect the reaction to this trading statement to be relatively muted this morning. While the weak renewable performance in January is balanced by a steady Q4 and has not impacted SSE’s guidance, we would expect a read-across to ORSTED and IBE.

FATDAZ on the subject of renewables was interested to see that solar panel installer is one of the fastest growing jobs in sunnier US states florida california arizona etc
BE11:54am

Oh, while on utils, Citigroup downgrade of Centrica's mildly interesting.

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 136.00, down 3.05 (-2.19%), High: 137.65, Low: 134.80, Volume: 5.19m
red i can see the sense in solar panels charging a large powerpack which sits on my drive and then can be used to charge an electric car but of course you can't do that as a) it makes sense b) governments seem to claim ownership of the sun and want it directed elsewhere.
11:54 am
BE11:55am

Centrica is struggling to demonstrate tangible success of its current strategy. A continuation of customer losses and two loss making growth businesses are struggling to convince the market of the company’s prospects. Where Centrica has done well, is the delivery of cost savings, although the impact on bottom line has been limited given the aforementioned challenges. With a new CFO onboard and Chairman due, we see this as a potential opportunity for Centrica to revisit its current strategy. In the absence of any major strategic update, we see Centrica’s adjusted OCF to be increasingly vulnerable to further unexpected events. In our view, Centrica will retain its current 12p DPS for FY19, although we expect the market to look through this.

BE11:56am

I think the growth bits referred to are Connected homes (ie, Hive installations) and Distributed Energy & Power (absolutely no idea)

BE11:56am

We have updated our valuation and forecast to reflect Centrica’s trading statement, recent movement in commodity prices and commodity output. As a result, we lower our 12m PT to 144p (from 160p) and we cut out 2018-21E EPS by -14% to -22%, including a £70m of one-off cost related to the price cap in FY19, currently in dispute with Ofgem under judicial review.
